values.alignmentText: Paris' compact arrondissements hide pockets of green like Parc des Buttes-Chaumont and the Coulée verte, yet we still escape to Fontainebleau forests for breathing room.
Average PM2.5 around 15 µg/m³ and NO2 spikes on périphérique ring roads mean we track smog alerts before long park days.
The 2024 SMIC near €1,766 gross a month outpaces many EU peers but remains tight once Paris rent and childcare enter the budget.
Senior engineers in Paris pull €65k–€90k with profit-sharing, enough for metro living but leaner than US remote offers after social charges.
La Défense banks, aerospace primes, and consultancies hire .NET teams steadily, especially with bilingual talent who can bridge legacy systems.
Rails powers scale-ups like Doctolib, Alan, and BlaBlaCar, giving Sarah healthy pipelines if she navigates French-language standups.
Hybrid schedules are normal three days a week, though purely remote contracts often expect periodic office weeks in Paris or Lyon.
Central arrondissements buzz late into the evening, so we'd likely settle in calmer suburbs like Montreuil or Issy to protect Sarah's slower cadence.
Parisian families rely on municipal crèches and free école maternelle from age three, but lotteries require early applications and backups with assistantes maternelles.
Once registered with CAF, visa holders can claim CMG reimbursements, yet French paperwork and processing lags mean we need cash flow for the first months.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries

values.alignmentText: From rooftop bars at Cité de la Mode to jazz cellars in Saint-Germain, Paris keeps world-class nightlife within a short metro ride for date nights.
Family flats inside the périphérique often exceed €2,800 monthly and demand guarantors; many expats choose RER-connected suburbs for space.
Violent crime stays low, yet pickpockets around Châtelet and protest marches require situational awareness with the kids.
Sixteen metro lines, RER express trains, and growing tram corridors make car-free living easy, especially once the Grand Paris Express opens new links.
Expect €4,000–€4,500 per month for housing, childcare, and transport in Paris; relocating to commuter towns trims costs but adds travel time.
Ubisoft, Dontnod, Quantic Dream, and Ankama recruit in Paris, while EU studios contract remote specialists, giving Trey steady opportunities.

As noted in Game Dev Work Prospects, Ubisoft, Dontnod, Quantic Dream, and Ankama recruit in Paris, while EU studios contract remote specialists, giving Trey steady opportunities. Hiring velocity at established studios in Paris wraps searches within a month or two as pipelines stay active.

Compensation remains competitive with other major hubs, mixing solid base pay and performance bonuses. When opportunities surface in Paris, established studios benchmark offers against peers across the ecosystem.
Established studios in Paris rely on English for cross-border collaboration, while local-language fluency remains important for community, compliance, and platform partnerships.
Remote expectations at established studios in Paris are flexible for senior roles, with hybrid schedules common.
Paris anchors Ubisoft HQ, Quantic Dream, and indie teams like Motion Twin, surrounding Trey with AAA and experimental peers.
Paris Games Week, Game Only meetups, and Women in Games France events keep the dev community active all year.
CNC grants, the Jeux Vidéo tax credit, and Station F incubators give Trey's studio realistic funding and mentorship paths.

Startup founders report that CNC grants, the Jeux Vidéo tax credit, and Station F incubators give Trey's studio realistic funding and mentorship paths. Hiring velocity at early-stage studios in Paris wraps searches within a month or two as pipelines stay active.
Compensation remains competitive with other major hubs, mixing solid base pay and performance bonuses. Early teams in Paris balance cash and equity to stay competitive while managing runway.
Founding teams in Paris lean on English for investor and platform communication, while local-language fluency helps with hiring, compliance, and community outreach.
Remote expectations among startups in Paris are flexible for senior roles, with hybrid schedules common.
Nationwide fiber, cashless transit gates, and the Grand Paris Express expansion keep infrastructure modern for a tech-focused family.
Extended daylight deficits and short, cloudy summers introduce ongoing mood strain the family must actively counter.
Comfortable windows exist but are short; we stack activities in one or two prime seasons.
Basic needs are met but savings and extracurriculars are hard to sustain without extra support or side work.
Housing and childcare strain the budget, limiting savings and discretionary spending most months.
Affluent households encounter noticeable friction—specialists, tutors, or clubs are scarce or highly gated.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Only a handful of listings surface each year; expect bidding wars and significant trade-offs.
Attitudes split; open discussion is fine in urban enclaves yet frowned upon elsewhere.
Mixed regulations mean some communities normalize casual carry; we stay aware of local norms.
Possession laws are moderate though some substances still carry steep fines.
Approach varies by district; we track neighborhood trends to avoid heavy-handed areas.
Multiple incidents within the past decade impact how we choose schools and venues.
We track reports to avoid complacency; advocacy groups monitor periodic abuses.
Sidewalks cover key areas but drivers often rush, so we stay alert with children.
Ultra-processed options crowd shelves; schools and events lean heavily on packaged snacks.
Strong selection overall though certain cuisines require a bit of travel.
We monitor diet and activity because obesity is moderately common.
Rates align with global norms; screening and early detection programs are reliable.
